results.title: [St Kilda Junction Overpass]
results.brief_description: Construction first began in 1970. This film explores not just the site construction but ambient shots of the surrounding traffic, footage of the W-class trams that graced the area and marvellous aerial shots of St Kilda, Albert Park and the newly constructed Dandenong Highway. (NOTE: Worksheet in HOLD file)

results.title: Skippy the Bush Kangaroo S01E20 "Double trouble" and S02E45 "Chicken"
results.creator_credit: Bob Austin, John McCallum, Lee Robinson, Max Varnel and Norfolk International Pictures
results.brief_description: Features two episodes of the television series. “Double trouble” looks at a rival who is trying to take control of the Waratah National Park; “Chicken” is about Skippy being poisoned by a local farmer who holds a grudge against the head ranger.

results.title: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @idkhowyoufoundme's TikTok stream
results.brief_description: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a text post on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also sometimes considered alongside the red/beige flag relationship trend and the popularity of stoicism videos on the manosphere.
results.title_for_label: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a question on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also at times considered alongside the ‘red/beige’ flag relationship trend and the popularity of ancient Western civilisation on the misogynistic manosphere.

According to Know Your Meme:

Many are wondering if it’s a “red flag” if their male partner thinks about the Roman empire all the time. In some of the videos, the men sometimes answer “never,” and in the comment section, many women joke, “He’s a keeper.”

That intersection between the Roman Empire trend and the ‘red flag’ trend can be interpreted as identifying toxic masculinity. Online trolls and misogynists are at times inspired by examples of hyper-masculinity in antiquity as justification for a return to outdated gender norms. Ronald Levant, a professor emeritus of psychology at The University of Akron and author of The Tough Standard: The Hard Truths About Masculinity and Violence told USA Today that men may “gravitate to a society that glorified male strength” as they feel lost in the world.
description_for_label: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, he goes from confused to defensive when he realises he actually thinks about Rome a lot, like many other men according to the virality of the trend. Though a light-hearted prank-style meme, it can also be interpreted as demonstrating the link between idolising ancient Western history and toxic masculinity. To find out how, collect this display on your Lens and read more online.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Xos: a cry for help
results.creator_credit: Alan Woodruff, Roberta Chuter and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Two transvestite brothers argue over the fate of their deceased grandmother: should she be buried in the family plot, or stuffed and placed beside her favourite dog?

results.title: Hey Marcel
results.brief_description: Images of figures descending staircases are orchestrated in four movements. Made with the assistance of the Creative Development Branch of the Australian Film Commission. Music by Bill McDonald; idea suggested by Chris Kennedy; lighting by Graeme Wood and David Lindsay. No spoken word.

results.title: My belle

results.title: Journey to the end of night
results.brief_description: Bill Neave, a World War II veteran, recounts his wartime experiences direct to the camera. The memories of these events are so vivid that he is still able to re-enact them and he does this on film, discussing such events with his long-dead friends. From an idea suggested and researched by Ruben Mow.

results.title: Lost in translation [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sofia Coppola, Ross Katz, American Zoetrope and Elemental Films
results.brief_description: Two kindred spirits, both hitched but essentially partnerless, seek solace and distraction in this updated take on “Brief encounter”. Bill Murray simply excels as Bob - a jaded film star whose career and marriage are sagging whilst he vaguely goes through the motions, resigned to the humiliations and compromises of middle age. Charlotte by contrast, still struggles with disappointment, set in early, of her marriage and the irony of her loneliness. The visual overload of a vibrant, tasteless, seedy, bustling, 24/7 Tokyo provides the backdrop to the pair’s melancholia and united quietude. Sophia Coppola was nominated for Best director, winning an Academy Award for her wonderfully droll and witty screenplay. Also stars Giovanni Ribisi.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sofia Coppola, Ross Katz, American Zoetrope and Elemental Films

holdings.name: DVD; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
This film comprises a slice of family life in suburban Melbourne.

The first scene shows children playing in their backyard under a homemade cubby house constructed of bed sheets, cardboard and possibly curtains. They play with long pieces of bamboo cane, running and dancing around the cubby house. We can see what is probably the rear of the house which is a mid-century modern style. The film shows backyard play equipment such as monkey bars and swings, and neighbouring houses appear in the background.

A young child dressed in cute overalls plays with a colourful ball and is joined by their mother and siblings. There is some lovely footage of the child standing on the garden path surrounded by flowers. A butterfly joins in as the toddler stops to pick some flowers.

The film shows some backyard above-ground swimming pool action. Children enjoy themselves duck-diving for coins, wearing diving masks and somersaulting under water. We see a delightful interaction between siblings as they sit in the sunshine and eat biscuits together.

We see a young child standing beside their mother. She is gardening dressed in her full-piece 1960s swimming costume.

Three children play together in a wading or paddling pool, filling it up with water from the nearby garden hose. They take great delight in creating a flood, squirting each other with water, splashing and jettisoning the water into the air. They play piggy-back in the pool, use plastic kickboards and sit in an improvised plastic boat.

The film shows scenes of children swimming laps in an outdoor inbuilt swimming pool which could be at St Catherine’s School, Toorak. We can see some impressive buildings in the background which could be a part of the school or neighbouring houses.

There is a lovely scene of a young boy riding his tricycle along a leafy suburban street, lined with large houses. The street could be Cleeve Court in Toorak.

We see a young girl playing on a swing surrounded by a beautiful garden in full bloom.

The film finishes with a trip to the country for horse riding lessons. We see the horses being saddled up while they stand under a Hills Hoist clothes line, and the children are taken through their rising trot and cantering paces. The horse riding instructors use wooden sign posts and mallets to mark out a course for the young horse riders.

This film shows great examples of fashion, including swimwear, children’s recreational activities including horse riding and swimming, play equipment, toys and architecture typical of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected Highlights list:
00:00:56:00 Children playing with long pieces of cane with mid-century modern house in background
00:03:36:00 Small boy and a butterfly on a garden path
00:05:29:00 Brother and sister sit by the swimming pool eating biscuits
00:07:43:00 Mother goes for a swim – good example of swimwear
00:08:35:00 Three children play in a wading pool
00:09:56:00 Children swim laps in an outdoor pool, perhaps at St Catherine’s School, Toorak
00:10:26:00 Children dive into an outdoor pool as above
00:10:37:00 Boy on tricycle riding down a street lined with grand houses, perhaps Cleeve Court, Toorak
00:11:25:00 Children play in wading pool with kickboards and improvised boat

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a schoolboy game of cricket being played on the turf wicket in the grounds of the Glamorgan Preparatory School in Toorak, Victoria. Glamorgan is the Toorak campus of the Geelong Grammar School in Geelong Victoria. The boys wear Geelong Grammar school caps. Behind the cricket pitch we can see the rooftops and chimneys of the grand homes of Toorak. There is a colourfully painted wall behind the cricketers depicting a scene of Governor Phillip raising the flag at Sydney Cove in 1788. A hand painted didactic says:
“Governor Phillip brought the First Fleet to anchor at Botany Bay but raised the flag at Sydney Cove January 26th 1788. This was the first Australia Day.”

We see the Glamorgan Vs Visitors scoreboard, runs being made, catches being taken and 4s being scored.

The film then takes us to a suburban backyard to show a young baby on a rug. There is some lovely footage of the baby trying to crawl, wearing a handmade necklace made from wooden cotton reels. The baby shares the backyard with other children who play on climbing equipment and engage with the baby.

We see a toddler dressed in rompers standing inside a playpen. The toddler pushes the playpen along from the inside, walking out onto a verandah. There is some delightful footage of a baby crawling along a garden path and playing in a container of water.

The film shows children playing and swimming in an above ground backyard swimming pool. They have kickboards and rubber rings which could be bicycle tyres. They take turns somersaulting into the water from the edge of the pool. After finishing swimming, and wrapped in towels, the children eat drum-stick style ice creams.

This film shows good examples of family at-home recreation and play equipment, including climbing equipment and a swimming pool. There are also examples of suburban architecture, children’s and babies’ fashion, baby paraphernalia such as a playpen, school sports playing fields and turf cricket.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:25:00 School cricket match with painted Australia Day/Governor Phillip scene behind
00:03:52:00 Glamorgan score board
00:05:21:00 School boys playing cricket, umpire (teacher) and painted wall behind
00:06:50:00 Baby with necklace of wooden cotton reels
00:09:08:00 Toddler inside playpen, walking out onto the verandah
00:09:28:00 Toddler crawls across the verandah
00:10:51:00 Toddler in rompers crawling along a garden path to play in container of water
00:14:01:00 Children playing in backyard pool
